my personal favorite of the trilogy (which might be my favorite trilogy of all time) I realize that the dark knight is objectively a better made film. But my love for this movie and the emotions I feel watching it are incomparable. I know this film has problems. But many of the "plot holes" arnt plot holes, but rather Nolans decision not to use blatant exposition, for example "how does Bruce get back in gotham?" simple. Wayne manor is not located on the main island. meaning. all of his shit is not on the main island, there are many other cases like this although there are plot holes, such as "how do they get dirt bikes inside the stock exchange" but my MAIN POINT, I hold this trilogy up with the original Star wars trilogy. And ROTJ is widely known as the least well made film with many problems, yet everyone (including me) overlooks these problems and excepts the movie as a great film because of the emotions it brings to us. So why can't people do the same for this film?ï»¿

I don't care what anyone says, this movie was incredible, and seeing it on the big screen made it a million times better, this trilogy has the best Batman story ever told, Nolan made it realistic, believable, and he picked probably the best choices for actors I've ever seen! Christian Bale you will always be Batman to me! (And for the butthurt Conroy fanboys, calm down, it's only something called an "Opinion" ;))ï»¿

@Andrew Hongâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹ It's funny I never once feared for Batman's life in BB and TDK.... coz I knew he would overcome the situation somehow - in Rises there are many instances where I actually thought Bruce wouldn't make it! Plus the villains like Ra's, Two-Face and Joker were in most cases justified as they actually saw humanity for what it really is. Bane and Talia are just plain evil - giving gothamites false hope before blowing them to hell.... That's villainy! Seeing a hero humiliated and vanquished was so unexpected and effective it made me actually care for Bruce more than ever! There was a lot at stake this time around... More emotional layers are in the third film - something I found lacking quite a bit in the first 2... Plus the SCALE!! Dear Lord!!ï»¿ï»¿
+Michael Otis I agree, fanboys are stupid. They think that just because something pays homage to the source it automatically makes it good. They are not true movie fans like I am.ï»¿
+Michael Otis You're right, in this movie, just like the rest, the way for Bruce to get through, was to think differently.ï»¿

@Israel Pallaresâ€‹ I musta been sleeping under a rock coz superhero films have changed these days. Instead of laying emphasis on the HERO bit more, it's all about the SUPER part - fight scenes, power showcasing and comic accuracy. It's like we've forgotten the importance of these stories. You see it in vapid fanboy debates over which portrayal was more accurate... Whatever happened to being INSPIRED AND UPLIFTED by these characters in costumes.. This for me is why Rises is my favorite. It takes artistic liberties yet somehow manages to produce an emotional character driven story of epic scale. It wasn't about the hero's origin (Begins) neither was it about the scene-stealing villain (Dark Knight) this time around - it was about a man transcending into the realm of legend. Finally becoming a symbol of hope for all to rise above their own damnation. That to me is the essence of a superhero character. ï»¿ï»¿

@Darin Dial People forget Bruce is still an orphan who never got over his past and since then has been looking for meaning in life. He found it by being Batman and was waiting for the day when the cape and cowl would no longer be necessary so he could go back to Rachel. But tragedy strikes and Rachel dies, with the Dent Act taking care of all organized crime. Now Bruce has no meaning - his Batman identity now a fugitive, his loved one departed and his company's clean energy project dead in the water. He is literally right back to square one - an orphan looking for anything just to matter. He was itching for things to go bad again - as Ra's said: a vigilante lost in the scramble for his own gratification This is why he had to reinvent himself like he did in Begins. This is why he earns his retirement with Selina Kyle, entrusting the secrets of the batcave to John Blake (another orphan like him) who we know will continue Batman's legacy in some way shape or form. ï»¿

Coz even the people who liked Rises don't even like it for the right reasons....ï»¿ they like it mostly coz it's a Batman film or coz it's got The Dark Knight afterglow....but as a film on its own it's near perfectï»¿ï»¿

+Michael Otis I absolutely appreciate and passionately love this trilogy, the first time I watched TDKR in theatres, I was literally shaking and on the edge of my seat. It was one of the best cinematic experiences I've ever had.ï»¿

@Israel Pallaresâ€‹ the third film had more tender and emotional moments - something I felt the previous films especially TDK lacked. Rises starts as a slow build, symbolising the false facade Gotham has thrived under for 8 years.... Gothamites just like the audience wonders when Batman will show up, so that when he DOES show up its worth the wait. The complaint of not enough Batman in Rises is actually a deliberate narrative device. It's more effective that Batman isn't constantly in the story, adding more weight and heft when Bruce dons the cape and cowl. Coz it means something epic or drastic is about to occur.ï»¿ï»¿

@Michael Otis I feel like TDK was more emotional and psychological in the series, the way the Joker turned Dent into a murderer, he took the best of Gotham and tor him apart, the way he was going to use Gordon's kids to punish him. ï»¿

@Israel Pallaresâ€‹ I would say TDK was leaning more on the psychological and philosophical.... Not emotional perse...  I mean take Alfred in Rises - loads of tender moments between him and Bruce, and the part where he cries I've failed you during Bruce's alleged funeral is just so sorrowful. Rises is basically the emotional aftermath of Joker's psychological attack on Gotham, how all the characters from Bruce to Gordon have been affected by Joker and Dent/Two-Face.... ï»¿ï»¿
@Michael Otis I guess I see more emotion in TDK because of Harvey's transformation.ï»¿

@Israel Pallares oh okay... I interpreted Dent's transformation as a psychological one. I mean I know he's being emotional by avenging Rachel's death, but if he were still emotional why didn't he kill Joker in the hospital? Why kidnap Gordon's family? Hell why even leave lives to chance with the flip of a coin? Sounds like a mentally broken man if you ask me...that's the essence of the Two-Face character ï»¿

@Michael Otis Because the Joker lied to him and explained how the system works. He kidnapped Gordon's family because Gordon was the one who could have saved her... he flips the coin because Rachel had a 50/50 chance of living and he said the only morality in a cruel world is chance.ï»¿

@Israel Pallares ya but that doesn't sound like revenge built on emotion to me... Don't get me wrong he certainly loved Rachel. What I'm saying is Dent's actions in the film's latter parts aren't exactly built on sentiment... Let's compare a similar instance in Begins where Bruce nearly kills Joe Chill. That had a genuine emotional undertone to it and Chill was the only one to blame. I doubt Bruce would have gone after Chills loved ones or something like that.... In the Dark Knight, Dent doesn't just want revenge for Rachel. He wants the whole system to pay since everything he's fought for as DA proved to be in vain (decent men in an indecent time). My point is it starts as him doing it to avenge Rachel, but then becomes something more. He's freeing himself of all responsibility and leaving it to chance. Even if Gordon is to blame, Dent will still leave killing him to the coin...hell he even says he doesn't want to "escape from this" -  It's like Joker says about madness being like gravityï»¿

@Michael Otis It's not Gordon's fault. He arrived as fast as he could and the joker lied to them about who was in which address. As soon as Gordon tried, the bomb blew up. But I feel it was emotional how Harvey took all of his frustration on the GCPD, once the joker told him how the system works, he lost all hope and faith.ï»¿

+Michael Otis Depending on which tone you likei like TDK more because the tone is dark,gritty and chaoticly fun i love Bane but Heath's Joker will always be my favourite in TDKR the tone is sad,  emotionally draining  and more into real drama in TDK it's more into a psychological action thriller depending which tone you like the most.ï»¿

@DeAth GaMingâ€‹â€‹ I always praise the trilogy for touching different themes yet still consistent in its narrative. Even some of the greatest trilogies like LOTR end up really being one story split into 3 halvesI like that some people like BB more or TDK more or TDKR more. It tells me people are affected differently with each film. Its not that one is the best or the worst, but what the audience expects going to see each film and what they took out of it.Whether its the sunset tone of BB telling a coming-of-age tale with fear as a main theme...... whether is the deep blue of TDK telling a crime drama with chaos as its central theme.....whether its the grey white of TDKR with its one-last-job-before-retirement trope focusing on physical & emotional pain... ï»¿ï»¿

@Ocram Immortoâ€‹ I know for a FACT that Affleck is a much competent director than Snyder and I have hope he won't fuck up his Batman films... Warner Bros just needs to quit playing catch up with Marvel. Unlike initially unpopular characters like Ironman, Thor and Guardians of the Galaxy that had to establish themselves to the general public, DC characters are already iconic - everyone knows Superman and Batman and the Justice League. Instead of replicating the MCU formula, DC needs visionary filmmakers and better scripts. Instead of trying to "fix" characters like superman and batman, they should embrace their core elements and expand on them. They should quit trying to be "realistic" like Nolan did for his trilogy - if marvel can let the absurdities of these comic characters shine without shame so can DCï»¿ï»¿

@Michael Otis Actually them playing catch up is the idea that we already know these folks, no need to origin story them again.  It's just BvS happens to be out of order from the rest of the other character's origin movies which not too many folks know the origins of.  But yeah, Snyder did a great job jumpstarting the DCEU, but should definitely take a backseat cause he struggles with handling his own original material, and Goyer just makes it worse.  I could tell at times in the ultimate cut that Chris Terrio was trying to salvage the story telling.  I have full faith in Affleck that he will do the character and mythos justice.  Cause 1 none of his films have been panned, and 2 there is just too much gold source material to reference from and innovate into the cinematic mythos Hush, possibly Death of Robin or Killing Joke flashbacks, No Man's Land, Court of Owls, Gates of Gotham, New52's Death of the Family, New52's Endgame, and possibly even Return of the Joker (could be DCEU's Days of Future Past).ï»¿

@Ocram Immortoâ€‹ by catch up I mean trying to force too much shit into one movie for future setups. By turning this Clark Kent into a brooding melancholic orphan searching for purpose (Bruce Wayne basically),  Goyer and Snyder have made an angsty alien not Superman. @Young Rainâ€‹â€‹ couldn't agree more. This trilogy really was a Bruce Wayne trilogy when you think about it. It's why it's so relatable and emotional. It's not the Gothic stylised exaggeration of the comics, it's a "what if Batman and his rogues were in our 21st century". If Dark Knight Returns did anything it proved that comic characters aren't set in stone - which is why I pay no mind to fanboys who want comic accuracy. I'm a comic fan and even I can say Nolan's Batman is my favorite. He isn't the 127 martial artist who's the world's greatest detective and can master knot-tying, lipreading, acrobatics all with an IQ of 192! He's just an orphan who never got over his past and is trying to find meaning and purpose - TDKR nails this core element the hardestï»¿ï»¿

@Israel Pallaresâ€‹ seriously dude how can ANYONE live up to Ledger's Joker! His performance is up there with Norman Bates, Alex Delarge and Hannibal Lecter...it's iconic and irreplaceable But here's the thing - I don't think Nolan was trying to outshine TDK! Why do you think there's no reference or mention of Joker in Rises... You could say it was paying respect to Ledger, but I think in Nolan's mind the Joker will always be Ledger. A recast was out of the question as nobody could do that particular reincarnation of the character justice. Hell the events in Rises occur 8 years after TDK - if you ask me Nolan was distancing himself completely from the second film narrative-wise. He just wanted to conclude Bruce Wayne's character arc (the trailer's tagline read "The Concluding Chapter"). This explains the many allusions to Batman Begins in Rises since everything was coming full circle. I think that's what many who disliked Rises didn't get. It should be viewed as a closing chapter of the Dark Knight not as a sequel perse. Bane was the perfect villain for Batman in this film. He and Talia are the actualization of Ra's immortality (this is Nolan's subtle nod since he chose to make his Batman universe grounded in reality) ï»¿ï»¿

@Israel Pallares I wouldn't go that far tho...  Talia's always been like a Bond Girl in the stories I've read and played. She wiggles her way into Bruce's life so unsuspecting, which is what the other villains really can't do - she's a BRUCE WAYNE villain, not necessarily a BATMAN villain. It's this personal connection that makes her formidable. In Rises we see a grieving suicidal bankrupt Bruce at his lowest point. Talia comes in like an oasis in a desert, wins his heart and confidence, and then able to access the fusion reactor - the very thing the League needs to destroy Gotham. ï»¿

Bane and Talia both planned all this from the CIA plane attack to bankrupting Wayne to using Daggett's cement to lace bombs... Bane protected her in prison after her mother was raped and killed, both survived together in that hell and as such share solidarity. What made The Dark Knight Trilogy so perfect was that Christopher Nolan rewrote the rules of what a Batman movie should be, and how you could make one.1. Make it yours.Put your own original spin on it, but still stay true to the source material. But if you have the right mind, you can make your take on Batman COMPLETELY your own!2. Have a soundtrack that suits the tone.The Dark Knight Trilogy was dark..... VERY dark. So it had an equally dark soundtrack. If you want to make a campy Batman, make the soundtrack campy. If you want a dark Batman, make it sound dark. If you want a healthy mix of both, then have the soundtrack be campy in one part, but dark in the next, and then BOTH in the next part!3. The characters and their overall look.Tim Burton mixed campy with dark. Nolan was realistic and dark. Snyder was...... a modern day The Dark Knight Returns.Depending on the type of Batman you want to make, make sure the outfit matches the tone of the Batman you're making. The same goes for the villains.4. The Joker.There must always be a Joker. Cesar Romero was Joker. Jack Nicholson was Joker. Mark Hamill is THE Joker. Heath Ledger was THE Joker. And Jared Leto WILL BE Joker. Once again, it depends on what kind of Batman it is. If it's animated, then make the Joker animated. But if the animation is meant to be more realistic and dark, try to follow the example of Brian Bolland's Joker from The Killing Joke. If it's a live-action Joker, find someone who can look and act like the Joker you are making.And finally:5. Bruce Wayne.Once you do the origin of Bruce Wayne, you're just repeating it like everyone else.........................which is perfectly fine. But, if you want to have him start out as Batman, then start him out as Batman. It's your choice, basically. As long as you put a unique spin on it.Not sure if these are Nolan's rules or mine. Either way, these are good rules to follow.ï»¿

I love TDK trilogy, I really do. But as a massive fan of Batman and superheroes in general, I don't see them as Batman or superhero movies. They're amazing movies, but to me they don't stand up to the Burton movies. ï»¿

@Bomberman101 yeah, but for me, that's what separates them from other superhero movies. they're not supposed to be comic book movies. they're meant to be a realistic take on it. they're more than just superhero movies. they're lousy comic book movies, for sure, but they're awesome movies. they're great movies but not great batman movies. and i think that's what makes them so good. it turns batman into a relatable figure, not a superhero figure, he's just a normal guy trying to stand up for what's right. that's why the villains aren't comic book-like too. in the comics, joker's face was bleached, but here, he just paints it. i feel like these movies are more drama, crime, and thriller movies than superhero movies . it's not supposed to be about the comic book batman. in a world where superheroes don't exist, this guy who just happens to be afraid of bats, puts on a costume and calls himself, "The Batman". i just feel like it was done better than a comic book adaptation of Batman.ï»¿

@Bomberman101 Are you fucked?Saying Burton films are better than Nolan's is like saying Crystal Skull was better than the original three. This was more faithful to the comics than Burton was. Jack napier? Lol.ï»¿
@regulator619 This was more faithful to the original comics (circa 1939), which most people can't grasp.ï»¿

@reallybeenfar Or they were called back by Bane since there was a massive army of cops gathering. A "all hands on deck" ordeal. The tunnel lead out of the city, it wasn't a tunnel to the sewers where the cops were held. That's why Blake tells the kids to tell the people to evacuate through the bridge of the tunnel. Yes, the LoS hid through the company of John Dagget which is what Bane needed him for. Bane is a jobber. The character did little of relevance after Knightfall. Yes, terrorize a city that his adversary loves so much that he's willing to risk his life protecting it and in turn have him watch it burn itself to the ground while he can do nothing about it. @reallybeenfar That was the tunnel out of the city not the tunnel to where the police were. They could have easily cut a scene where catwoman dealt with the guards for pacing reasons because you don't need it. Or, as I already suggested, they were called off to deal with the cops. You're just wrong about this part not making sense, deal with it.Also your claim that it's a generic plot is only remotely defensible if you ridiculously oversimplify it. You might as well say it's generic because there's a city threatened by a bad guy and superhero saves the day at the end. Or it's generic because it depicts a protagonist who engages in some sort of conflict, and the tension rises throughout until the climax, when the protagonist succeeds in overcoming the conflict. If a movie can't be good if it in any way does something similar to another movie, we could never have another good movie. What makes this movie unique, or at least uncommon, is the manner in which the city is terrorized. The part about Bane turning the city over to whoever is strong enough to take what they want is a critical detail. It shows why law and order are important, and it shows the difference between true justice and the justice of mob rule. I'm not saying it's perfect. I'll admit I was disappointed that we didn't get to see more ordinary gothamites take up the cause of defending their city. It ended up coming down to a battle between police and Bane's thugs, which I thought was a bit heavy-handed and silly. But if you're going to claim it's stupid and want anyone to agree with you, you need to come to the table with some specific claims that are actually defensible. So far I haven't seen any other than your critique about it being dumb for the cops to send everyone into the sewer. That I agree was a poorly conceived plot point.Finally going back to your original claim about Batman not being in the movie enough, that's a fine complaint in terms of dashed expectations. However, it doesn't make the movie objectively bad. The Nolan Batman films are not really about Batman the character, they are about Bruce Wayne, who dons the Batman persona at times to accomplish certain things. In the TDKR it just happens that he doesn't have a lot of opportunity to wear the outfit. That's only bad if Bruce Wayne is objectively boring, but I would argue that's a matter of taste. I thought his personal struggle in TDKR was very compelling, so I didn't notice or care that he wasn't Batman for very long.ï»¿

It ties up everything from the first two. The first one Bruce wayne wanted to inspire Gotham's citizens with a symbol and in the process he could become a legend. Part 2 Joker has Batman rethinking his decision because he inspired this evil man to do theatrics to do evil things. Batman himself is riding that fine line between crazy and sane in these movies. That's reason he will not kill because it separates him from the criminals. So Joker is playing these mind games trying to get Batman to kill so the Joker can prove Batman is just like him. And in part three all those secrets come out and Gotham basically turns to hell on earth and Batman is forced to watch then he will be executed by bane. I'm a huge Batman fan, but after watching Batman Begins I was really reluctant on watching the others, because the 1989 Batman set the scene for the whole Batman movie franchise, but the others didn't stick with the storyline that was created and it just got confusing.Â Take the Dark Knight for example, it says that some random guy killed Bruce's mum and dad, but in the original Batman it was actually Jack (the Joker) who killed them. I wish the new Batman movies would just forget about trying to make amazing special effects and instead refocus on the brilliant story lines and villains, because that's what sets Batman and DC comics apart from freaking Marvel. (Just my educated opinion) :)Â ï»¿

"Batman" from '89 wasn't all that true to the comics. Joe Chill actually was the guy that killed Bruce's parents. The character "Jack" was not part of the comics, nor did he kill the Waynes. The most accepted origin of Joker was The Killing Joke where he reminisces and he was in the Red Hood suit when he fell into the cat of chemicals. The Tim Burton films were great, and an interesting adaption of the comics. The Chris Nolan movies were great, and an interesting and more realistic imagining of the comics. I personally enjoy the Nolan films more because of the realism and terror, but I still love Jack Nicholson's evil Joker smile. It's all preferences :Pï»¿

Many even complained about a review without even watching the movie. So, the problem of haters is not with the movie itself, but with the movie (and director) fans. And the way to attack movie fans is to attack the movie itself (this happens also in music, sports, etc). I am not saying that is the right way to do it, cuz Nolan usually makes pretty good movies (even this one i think is worth the time)I read many reviews in rotten tomatoes, but i only agree with this one "There was an opportunity here for Nolan to show us another way, to (again) stretch the boundaries of what is possible in a superhero film. Instead, alas, the latter half of The Dark Knight Rises retreats toward conventionality."Â Â I got disappointed, but not with the movie in comparisson with the other two movies of the trilogy, but with the movie itself. I can understand if people don't like Rises as much as The Dark Knight. I can easily see why people would say prefer the Joker over Bane, and so forth. But I have a hard time just looking at this as just a generic blockbuster action-film like Prometheus (Yes some people have actually made that comparison).The action scenes are mostly practical effects, while someone like Michael Bay would use CGI for everything. The plot is creative, and the themes of revolution and social classes are interesting. The Journey of Bruce Wayne is fascinating and emotional, and the ending is one of the best I've ever seen.The plotholes are there sure, there's a little too much exposition yes, and Bale's voice can be silly at times. But I still enjoy this movie for it's ambition, creative story, it's villain, the subtle themes, etc.With that said, The Dark Knight is better. That movie was the natural evolution of traditional Batman story-telling.ï»¿

@Jim Fitton I see your point. I have thought about if Bane's desire was just to take down Gotham's wealthier citizens. Perhaps he was a victim of Gotham's new laws and wanted revenge or justice. The whole idea of him using a revolution as a cover intrigued me though since political figures have manipulated citizens and taken advantage of convenient situations to further their own goals before. I saw Bane as the fascist and Batman as the democrat since he knew EVERYONE was going to die by Bane's hands and wanted to stop that. And he does shows awareness of Gotham's current state before Bane's revolution.A personal opinion of my though is that the League of Shadows shouldn't be part of the story. They kind of confuse the themes, and it adds to the feel that your watching Batman Begins again.When it comes to Batman rising twice, I sadly don't agree. When he chases Bane's goons on the Batpod he's not himself, it's just for show. The way I interpret it is that Batman doesn't care about his life any longer, and Alfred tries to tell him that. He finally learns to live again when he climbs out of the pit. With all due respect I'm not very fond of Frank Miller. He created two great Batman stories, but after that he went nuts. In his eyes, Batman is the kind of person who would abuse children, boast about how awesome he is, and pick fights with Superman because he can. I am really not looking forward to TDK3: The Master Race. Seriously I really don't like what that title may imply.And I guess I can't blame you for having that nitpick. I hate those scenes in films when someone is trying to tell the police about something they of course won't believe. Pointless to the story in my opinion.ï»¿

@Slifer Soul "Generic blockbuster action-film like Prometheus" I wouldn't agree there, Prometheus was fairly well made. It wasn't perfect, it had plot holes though it was still a fascinating movie to some. It was a horror movie, though had deeper elements of a mysterious plot with aliens with questions that were left to the audience to solve. The mysteriousness of the movie is what sold it for me. I can't call The Dark Knight better or worse than The Dark Knight Rises, truly The Dark Knight also tackled social issues as well and went on to give truly in depth dialogue between the characters Batman and The Joker to dig deeper into their motivations. People like The Dark Knight better than Rises, because it had more action, also it felt more like a complete experience at first. When Rises has a much more complicated level of story telling, it took me multiple viewings to fully appreciate the movie. I can't find a single thing wrong with it in the end, it was deeply emotional and it wasn't hard to imagine everything that was happening in the film was real. People are so used to hyped up action sequences, and delivered quick thrills that compared to that The Dark Knight Rises was more of a somber, and subtle movie at times seeking to rely on more dramatic scenes than action. It still had plenty of scenes that were impressive.ï»¿

Subtle may be the last word I would use to describe this movie. Everything it has to say about terrorism, social classes, etc., is expressed through text, not subtext, which almost makes the film seem condescending and pretentious.ï»¿
